23924522.trustfund:
TF027163-PHRD-FIRST EDUCATION PROJ. (BANK-EXECUTED),TF029612-PHRD-FIRST EDUCATION PROJ.(RECIPIENT-EXEC.),TF036673-SOUTH EAST ASIA REGION -
            EDUCATION PROJECTS (VIETNAM AND CAMBODIA)

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial, including satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Several lessons
            are drawn from implementation of the project, as follows. It
            is suggested that upon introducing innovations to promote
            changes in educational quality, a gradual building on the
            concept of effective schools from the ground up is critical,
            beginning with essential inputs of supplies, teacher
            training and basic management practices. However, in-service
            teacher training must have strong connections with the
            mainstream teacher training department, and institutions if
            the programs are to have enduring benefits. Next, in order
            to change attitudes, and pedagogical practices at the
            classroom level, sustained efforts over time are required,
            and support at all management and policymaking levels.
            Particularly important for change are those at the central,
            provincial and district levels, in a context where
            hierarchal relations are dominant. Furthermore, technical
            assistance is important to infuse new ideas, and their
            continuous reinforcement. Capacity building is a necessary
            condition to effect lasting institutional change. This is
            especially important, and useful at decentralized levels.
            Lessons outline the constraints of the environment, and work
            within existing structures, suggesting strong, and open
            communication with policymakers at the national level,
            required in particular, for innovation programs supported by
            continuous supervision, and effective monitoring and
            evaluation systems.

TF027163-PHRD-FIRST EDUCATION PROJ. (BANK-EXECUTED),TF029612-PHRD-FIRST EDUCATION PROJ.(RECIPIENT-EXEC.),TF036673-SOUTH EAST ASIA REGION -

repnme.cdata!: Cambodia - Helping communities help their schools

abstracts.cdata!:
Cambodia's education system was
            devastated in the 1970s by war and continues to suffer.
            Through the education quality improvement program, which is
            funded by a United States (U.S.) 5 million dollars learning
            and innovation credit, teachers, and communities from Takeo,
            Kandal, and Kampot provinces are coming together in
            workshops to talk about ways to improve their schools. This
            bottom-up approach is a radical change in the way education
            has been managed in Cambodia, which is in the process of
            decentralizing its highly centralized education system. By
            helping communities and teachers have a stake in their local
            schools; Cambodian children can have a chance at a better future.

5084650.trustfund:
TF027163-PHRD-FIRST EDUCATION PROJ. (BANK-EXECUTED),TF036673-SOUTH EAST ASIA REGION -
            EDUCATION PROJECTS (VIETNAM AND CAMBODIA)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Quality Improvement
            Project for Cambodia aims to develop a demonstration model,
            shown to be effective for extension to other provinces, of a
            participatory approach to school quality improvement and
            performance-based resource management. The project has two
            main components. The first component finances a quality
            improvement grants program that 1) recruits and trains
            "animators" (or "lightning rods") who
            work with community and school cluster leaders to engage
            them in discussions about effective schools, in identifying
            problems and solutions, and in developing cluster
            improvement plans as a basis for preparing grant proposals;
            2) supports a provincial grants management committee which
            meets annually to review proposals; 3) provides quality
            improvement grants to school clusters; 4) and supplies
            training, monitoring, and evaluation funds for activities
            related to the professional development of animators as well
            as assisting in monitoring and evaluating grants by other
            officials. The second component supports the institutional
            strengthening/capacity building of Cambodia's education
            sector by supporting the National Committee on Effective
            Schooling; funding policy studies, including grade four
            examinations and decentralization); and providing
            operational support for provincial and district education offices.
